snippet: Two days before the papal conclave begins, the cardinals adhered to what might be called the art of running for pope, which means never, ever appearing to be running.
abstract: Cardinals in Rome gathered for papal conclave carefully avoid acting like they are running for pope; journalists and much of Catholic world try to interpret gestures and measure papal intangibles.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Rachel Donadio, Daniel J. Wakin, Michael Paulson, Elisabetta Povoledo and Gaia Pianigiani.

lead_paragraph: Two days before the papal conclave begins, the cardinals adhered to what might be called the art of running for pope, which means never, ever appearing to be running.

headline.seo: Ahead of Conclave, Papal Candidates Visit Rome Churches
headline.main: No Stumping for Papacy, but Babies Do Get Kisses
headline.print_headline: No Stumping For Papacy, But Babies Do Get Kisses
